title: It’s the Cloth, Not the Image
post:
Further to the previous comments, it must be stated that Barth has been taken out of context. He was simply saying the obvious. Why? If Jesus came into our world as a divine being he also had to leave it in the same condition. The Protestant biblical scholar Ernst Käsemann described the whole scene in a different way, with no reference to mangers or tombs: Jesus is the only manifestation of God that Christians can see. It is a definition that can be accepted without hesitation by all Christians, whether liberal or conservative, in an increasingly sceptical (Western) world.
The Turin Shroud is said to be Jesus’ burial cloth, not the nappie he used in the manger.
There is a hidden agenda behind this. What is it? It is a cult-like devotion to Ray Rogers. Poor Barth must have turned over in his grave.
author: Louis

title: It’s the Cloth, Not the Image
post:
“Is it possible that the most important message of the Shroud concerns primarily the greatness of the love of God for all humanity much more than his own personal Resurrection, while showing us in graphic detail where such a God was willing to go with his human body in order to reveal to us that his merciful love for every human being has absolutely no limit at all when it’s time to save even the most lost of his children and, consequently, we have absolutely no good or rational reasons to fear such a loving and merciful God and to fear for our eternal salvation?”
Beautiful statement, I wholeheartedly agree. The shroud has always been to me a 21century opportunity to “Behold the man” and decide on the question “Who do you say that I am?”
